item.title: Microsoft Submits Revised Activision Deal to U.K. Watchdog
item.description: The new proposal is an effort to win approval for a $75 billion deal to acquire the videogame maker after the competition agency rejected it earlier this year.

item.title: Weaker Demand to Keep Pressure on Aluminum
item.description: Weak global demand and a lack of significant stimulus from China is likely to keep the pressure on aluminum prices this year, BMI said, lowering its average price estimate for 2023 to $2,300 a metric ton.

item.title: U.S. 10-Year Treasury Yield May Extend Strong Uptrend, Charts Show
item.description: The 10-year Treasury yield may extend its strong uptrend after breaking above last year’s high of 4.338% on Monday to reach 4.354%, its highest level since November 2007, UOB said.

item.title: Microsoft Proposes New Deal for Activision
item.description: The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority said that Microsoft has submitted a new deal to buy Activision, but will not acquire the cloud streaming rights to current and future Activision games released during the next 15 years, excluding the EEA.

item.title: Woodside Energy CEO Upbeat About Resolving Labor Dispute
item.description: Woodside Energy is making good progress toward resolving a labor dispute in Australia that has jolted natural gas markets worldwide, Chief Executive Meg O’Neill said.

item.title: BRICS Meeting Could Weigh on Dollar
item.description: The summit of BRICS countries this week could cause the dollar to fall, DZ Bank Research said, as “the question here will inevitably be whether and how countries can bid farewell to their heavy dependence on the overpowering dollar.”

item.title: Afghans Who Allied With U.S. Face Killings, Arrests Under Taliban Rule, U.N. Finds
item.description: The findings of the U.N. report are at odds with the amnesty declared by the Taliban for all former officials, after their fighters walked into Kabul in August 2021.

item.title: Nikkei Rises 0.9% as Banking Shares Gain
item.description: Japanese stocks ended higher, led by gains in banks as long-term government bond yields climbed.

item.title: Geely Automobile Posts Flat First-Half Net Profit
item.description: Geely Automobile Holdings posted a flat first-half net profit despite higher revenue, as its gross profit margin was hurt by intensifying competition in the automobile market.

item.title: How Hard Should the Fed Squeeze to Reach 2% Inflation?
item.description: The strategy the central bank adopts to fight the last mile of inflation has big, potentially painful implications for consumers, the markets and the economy.

item.title: Iowa's most closely watched poll shows that 42% of GOP caucus-goers say Trump is their first choice for president, while 19% pick DeSantis.
item.description: Iowa’s most closely watched poll shows that 42% of GOP caucus-goers say Trump is their first choice for president, while 19% pick DeSantis.

item.title: Arm, whose circuit designs lie inside billions of mobile phones, said quarterly profit fell by more than 50% in filings that kicked off whatis expected to be the biggest IPO of the year.
item.description: Arm, whose circuit designs lie inside billions of mobile phones, said quarterly profit fell by more than 50% in filings that kicked off whatis expected to be the biggest IPO of the year.

item.title: Surging prices of new and used cars have become a burden on many consumers, with rates of severe delinquency for auto loans at a 17-year high.
item.description: Surging prices of new and used cars have become a burden on many consumers, with rates of severe delinquency for auto loans at a 17-year high.

item.title: Retailers are on track to open 1,000 net new stores in the U.S. this year as retail availability hits record lows, in fresh signs of the sector's resilience despite turmoil in commercial real estate.
item.description: Retailers are on track to open 1,000 net new stores in the U.S. this year as retail availability hits record lows, in fresh signs of the sector’s resilience despite turmoil in commercial real estate.

item.title: The popularity of Ozempic and similar weight-loss drugs is driving big business for some pharmaceutical distributors, but logistics costs are cutting into their bottom line.
item.description: The popularity of Ozempic and similar weight-loss drugs is driving big business for some pharmaceutical distributors, but logistics costs are cutting into their bottom line.

item.title: Drugmaker Teva agreed to pay $225 million to settle criminal charges over price-fixing allegations related to cholesterol medication and other drugs.
item.description: Drugmaker Teva agreed to pay $225 million to settle criminal charges over price-fixing allegations related to cholesterol medication and other drugs.

item.title: Pay for new hires is starting to shrivel after years of hefty salary bumps, requiring workers to reset what financial gains to expect from switching to a new job.
item.description: Pay for new hires is starting to shrivel after years of hefty salary bumps, requiring workers to reset what financial gains to expect from switching to a new job.

item.title: Trump's bond was set at $200,000 on criminal election-interference charges in Georgia, and he agreed to surrender in the case Thursday.
item.description: Trump’s bond was set at $200,000 on criminal election-interference charges in Georgia, and he agreed to surrender in the case Thursday.

item.title: Japan said it planned to begin the discharge of slightly radioactive wastewater from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant this week, rejecting calls for a delay.
item.description: Japan said it planned to begin the discharge of slightly radioactive wastewater from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant this week, rejecting calls for a delay.

item.title: China is playing a key role in propping up Russia's economy and helping boost its war effort, with recent trade data showing Beijing providing a range of goods, including some with potential military applications such as chips and trench-digging excavators.
item.description: China is playing a key role in propping up Russia’s economy and helping boost its war effort, with recent trade data showing Beijing providing a range of goods, including some with potential military applications such as chips and trench-digging excavators.
